H0.text: Upwelling is the wind‑water interaction responsible for cycling nutrient‑rich waters from the ocean floor to the sea surface.

H1.text: Storm surge is the wind‑water interaction responsible for cycling nutrient‑rich waters from the ocean floor to the sea surface.

H2.text: Downwelling is the wind‑water interaction responsible for cycling nutrient‑rich waters from the ocean floor to the sea surface.

H3.text: Surface currents are the wind‑water interaction that cycles nutrient‑rich waters from the ocean floor to the sea surface.

A4.text: Upwelling is an oceanographic phenomenon that involves wind-driven motion of dense, cooler, and usually nutrient-rich water from deep water towards the ocean surface.

A5.text: The three main drivers that work together to cause upwelling are wind, Coriolis effect, and Ekman transport.
